displayed_text: Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: FDA approved. We would do a different chemo. I wouldn’t repeat the same chemo but it’s a cousin drug so it’s still once every three weeks just like before. Okay, the pills are four pills a day every day. Patient: For the rest of your life? Doctor: Yeah, until it stops working, which at some point after a couple years it sort of poops out and stops working. So, we have studies there too. So, you got to say okay, what’s this study with the chemo. Well, you know in Oncology we love to combine stuff so the study is either the pill or chemo plus the pill. I know. So, it’s a win-win in the sense that you either get the pill get the pill that you were going to get anyways Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: or you actually get the double whammy and you get the pill and Patient: and the chemo. Doctor: the chemo and that’s a nationwide study so, you know, we would pretty much kind of consider that one for you. And then there’s another trial of just pills. You say, listen, Dr. H____ there’s no way your’e giving me any more chemo, get away from me, then there’s a study with two pills so the one pill that I would offer you and then another pill that is also FDA approved but you know in cancer it’s like hey, one’s good, let’s try two. So, the combo isn’t chemo plus pill, but it’s pill plus pill. How are we doing? Patient: I’m there. Doctor: Yeah, I can see it. It’s kind of a lot but the good news is there’s a lot of options and that’s me banking on everything as the worse-case scenario as, you know, you know, Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: that’s how I am because I don’t want you to fret that there’s nothing to do after we get the scans. We have tons of stuff to do. It’s just being thoughtful about what you want in terms of what’s the best thing. Questions? Patient: Not on that. I had one other.

Patient: Yeah. I’m gonna have a great time on my bike. Doctor: Okay. Just be careful. People worry. That’s all. Patient: I know, I know. I know how to you know make her shut it down. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Call me if you run into trouble. If there’s issues with your insurance we will let you know. Patient: Well doc we ain’t claiming that. Remember you said that last time and we made it. Doctor: I know. Patient: Alright. Love you doc. Doctor: Love you too. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Be well. Patient: Yep.

Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: The other things we’re looking at is keeping the male castrated so all the prostate genes are turned off, and then after the new bone marrow gets all happy, you get a couple of pulse of testosterone, not to treat the cancer but to turn on the genes. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: To get the immune system. This new immune system, saying what the hell is that? It’s almost like an infection. So we’re in the early stages. We’ve treated two men. I can’t say much other than you know they did pretty well with the transplant part. Uh we’re following them. It’s really designed, my idea is for younger men, you know, less than seventy, and that is younger for me, uh, where, you know, unfortunately, you know prostate cancer grows slowly in most men. You’re probably going to live long enough that this is you know could be really- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, we’re, we’re uh cautiously optimistic. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: We’re also starting a study probably not for a few months yet though. We’ve had two patients now who got testosterone. They both responded to testosterone but we then put them on something for the immune therapies, just not a trial, just hit or miss. And both of those two patients had incredible response to immune therapy. Patient: Hum. Doctor: So they started like negative something, so we’re going to try a trial where we are going to prime the cancer. Not actually treat it just to get the cancer you know. We think the testosterone potentially changes the cancer, the DNA of the cancer, and maybe that makes the cancer more recognizable by the immune system. So that’s- Patient: so it would somebody who just had the- Doctor: The trial is to get testosterone for three doses and then get immune therapy. Family Member: Well you couldn’t just do that as, like say you try it on those two guys, don’t you just try that with B__, knowing that there is still Germany, but um-?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: that is not immediately making us have to worry from a treatment standpoint. Patient: Right. Doctor: But the rest of you, if I want to get better control of this situation – Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: - it’s better that we start thinking about doing this medicine. Patient: Mm, hmm. So what else, what is the other um other than the weakness, the tiredness? Doctor: The other one is we monitor your liver numbers and we do that by blood tests. You know I always check your blood when you come in. Patient: Man… Doctor: We check out your liver and make sure it’s tolerating it. Patient: They’re taking ten or twelve tubes doc every time I get there but I got a good vampire. Doctor: You do, you do have a good vampire. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Just physically tired? Doctor: Physically tired and it’s a weirder tired not like you worked out in the yard for twelve hours and can’t do much, it’s just no get up and go. If that happens, we take a break and we reduce the medicine dose. Patient: Let me ask you something doc. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Can we, can we provide a pill that would give me a little, like a vitamin that would give me a little energy? Doctor: No I think the issue of you not having as much energy is that your cancer is starting to, sorry that your thing is starting to break through slowly, Patient: Right. Doctor: but I don’t want to be on the back end because you you know in the story that you didn’t share Patient: Yeah. Doctor: with all the stuff related to what you’ve been doing with Dr. P____. Patient: Right. Doctor: That’s a whole ‘nother situation as you know Patient: Yeah.

Family Member: To the next person who needs it. Doctor: And we have a process to do that. Family Member: Somebody that needs it because I know how expensive it is. Doctor: Yes, and we appreciate that. Family Member: Yeah, we’ll bring it back. Doctor: Okay, sounds like a plan. Family Member: So he won’t get; will he – does he need nausea medication for this drug or anything? Doctor: Typically not; obviously we can, oh you know, he’s such a typical guy. But yes, Dr. ___ can prescribe that because he has a set thing because this is his program to run. So I’m just hovering nearby. Family Member: I think he was the one that actually diagnosed you with cancer when I told him to do the bone scan. Doctor: Oh my gosh! That’s been a long time then. Patient: Yes. Family Member: Yeah, because he was just going to start him on radiation and I go well - Doctor: No, he saw Dr. ___ in O____ when I was there many moons ago.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: I’ve gotta box this up. You know? As it was I was a little bit late Family Member: You ate half of it. Doctor: No. That’s okay. You should never rush to come here. You know that. You just come when you can safely. I’m not going anywhere. So next time just finish whatever you’ve gotta finish. Patient: Well, we, we, we, started now much late. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But then we ran into,there’s a ballgame. Doctor: I heard there was something going on seventy-five today too. Patient: Middle of that, yes. Doctor: There was some massive drama on seventy-five. Family Member: Oh. Hope we missed it. Patient: No. We ran into it. Doctor: But it was south of here. Something happened south.

Patient: Yes. Doctor: But let’s hope for the best. Patient: We’ll be in our faith, so we’ll keep on looking up. Doctor: Me too. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So that makes two of us. Patient: Okay. We’re done? I think we got it okay. I want to make sure. Family Member: Aside from the fact, do we have an appointment time for September fifth? Only because I just need to know so that if I need to adjust my schedule at school, um, so. Healthcare Professional: So, September fifth, nine-thirty lab work, and ten-thirty, the visit. So the time is nine-thirty to ten-thirty. Family Member: Now, for the next, I guess, will be continue to have doctor at ten-thirty? Doctor: Not necessarily. If you wants them at K___, who’s there that day, what the schedule looks like. Do you prefer later or earlier? Family Member: Mm, I mean. Doctor: Yeah. L___ can help with scheduling. If you prefer, like an afternoon appointment, let’s say, instead of morning, or if you want to be like the very first patient that comes in. The lab I think opens at six a.m. So we have some patients that come like at six and then see that doctor. Most people don’t want to come that early.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So the theory is vitamin C in high doses may have a, let you have less side effects from the chemotherapy. Huh, at high doses, it may make the chemotherapy work better. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Old data says that sometimes if you take too much vitamin C when you’re getting chemotherapy it could protect the cells, in this case the cancer cells, which we don’t want to protect, and maybe make the chemo work less well. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But have less side effects. Okay? So that’s why we have the dummy pill. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because most of what we’re looking for is how you feel. Oh, I’m having nausea. No. I’m not having nausea. Oh, this was a cakewalk. Oh, my fingers aren’t numb. Huh, my counts, huh, you know, are fine. Things that we’re going to be testing. So then we can sort of compare what blood test and symptoms are for those who actually get the vitamin C versus those who don’t. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So you have a fifty-fifty chance that you’re going to get the real stuff. Huh, you know, there is some flexibility. They want you here at least twice a week. But you know, if you’re going to go on holiday or something, you know, we can switch it. Huh, so far we know that giving high doses of vitamin C is safe. Huh, we haven’t seen many real extra side effects. But we don’t know the end of the answer. Does it help with side effects? Does it help activity? Or is there no difference? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so you would be potentially eligible for that. Huh, if you do a clinical trial, it does slow down a little bit when we get started. Okay? Huh, because we would first want to check your insurance company that they will pay for the clinical trial. You’re not on Medicare yet. You’re not sixty-five. Patient: Right.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: You’ll either know today or they may have to call you once they put you on the schedule. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Family Member: And then how long after that scope thing? Doctor: Usually then he’ll pick a date so. Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: He’ll probably tell you on that day – Family Member: Uh huh. Doctor: When you’re likely to get… Do you have anything going on that you want us to work around then let them know at that time? Patient: That we probably can’t change. Doctor: Okay. Patient: The doctors you know.

Patient: Alright. Appreciate it. Doctor: Safe travels. Patient: Same to you. Doctor: Are you going back to F___? Patient: We are, later today. Doctor: Snow in N__, really crazy? Patient: It was cold. It was in the, in the thirties that night, but it’s back up in the seventies now. Doctor: Well you’re also in N__t so you’re used to that? Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Do you, you have my phone information? Patient: I don’t think I have your e-mail. Doctor: Do you want it? Do you want a phone? I could use yours too. Okay? Uh, here’s my card. So my office is here. Well your phone number is in here. Just give it to me on the back of the card.

Patient: I guess I can cross that off my list (chuckles) Doctor: Yeah, I think. Patient: Oh did you get a new car yet? Doctor: I did. UNISON OH! Healthcare Professional: Oh you got a new car? Family Member: Oh no, you’re kidding. Doctor: Well I did because my daughter has taken mine. So I badly needed one. I mean I needed a set of wheels for sure. Family Member: Oh! Doctor: So it wasn’t by choice. Healthcare Professional: What kind of car did you get? Family Member: Did you get your Caddy? Doctor: I did not. No, he wanted me to get a Cadillac. No, no, I got a Mercedes. Family Member: Oh, all right!

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: It’s just for a period of time. And then the last third, the cancer continued to grow at roughly the same pace that it was growing before. Patient: How so? Doctor: So the therapy did not appear to be effective. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But it also did not appear to accelerate or worsen the cancer. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: And uh the study that we have, which we have open right now is called the Transformer Trial. It’s an acronym. You don’t need to remember that. We’ll give you information about that – to read it. Patient: I appreciate that, thanks. Doctor: It’s called the Transformer Trial because it was funded by a grant that was called the Transformative Impact Grant. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And so we applied for a grant at the Department of Defense, actually, DOD. And they have a program whereby they support prostate cancer studies. Patient: DOD?

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay so the leg nerves are running further down. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But I mean technically yes, if there is a clean total cut of the cord or major pressure at that level, it can affect the arms and the legs. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Because I have pain walking upstairs. Doctor: Sort of the Christopher Reeve’s spot – Family Member: Okay. Doctor: - that’s where he was hurt. Family Member: Oh is it? Doctor: Yeah. Right at the neck, the spine. Patient: But you can have atherosclerotic arteries that cause pain too. Doctor: Are you feeling like pain is that why you’re asking this?

Healthcare Professional: - after that spot. It’s… Or are you worried that it will drop the PSA and not necessarily correlate the scans? Doctor: Uh if the PSA drops it means the cancer is done. Healthcare Professional: Yes, so because it could be the PSA coming from that one area. Doctor: Right, right, correct. Healthcare Professional: And if you zap that and you see the PSA drop, that’s good. Patient: So uh hum, okay, okay. Doctor: It’s not going to drop by like ninety-nine percent. So don’t expect; with hormone therapy, that’s what usually happens - Patient: Yeah I got it. Doctor: - You get a dramatic drop. When you get a drop because cancer is dying. With this, if this was truly the only lymph node. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: You know then you would expect the PSA to drop by like ninety percent. Family Member: Uh hum.
